entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French servise, from Latin servitium condition of a slave, body of slaves, from servus slave

def.dt: :the occupation or function of serving in active service
:employment as a servant entered his service
:the work performed by one that serves good service
:help use benefit glad to be of service
:contribution to the welfare of others
:disposal for use I'm entirely at your service
:a form followed in worship or in a religious ceremony the burial service
:a meeting for worship often used in plural held evening services
:the act of serving: as
:a helpful act did him a service
:useful labor that does not produce a tangible commodity usually used in plural charge for professional services
:serve
:a set of articles for a particular use a silver tea service
:an administrative division (as of a government or business) the consular service
:one of a nation's military forces (as the army or navy)
:a facility supplying some public demand telephone service bus service
:a facility providing maintenance and repair television service
:the materials (as spun yarn, small lines, or canvas) used for serving a rope
:the act of bringing a legal writ, process, or summons to notice as prescribed by law
:the act of a male animal copulating with a female animal
:a branch of a hospital medical staff devoted to a particular specialty obstetrical service
:to perform services for: as
:to repair or provide maintenance for serviced the furnace
:to meet interest and sinking fund payments on (as government debt)
:to perform any of the business functions auxiliary to production or distribution of
:serve 10
:of or relating to the armed services
:used in serving or supplying delivery men use the service entrance
:intended for hard or everyday use
:providing services the service trades—from filling stations to universities John Fischer
:offering repair, maintenance, or incidental services

entry.et: Middle English serves, plural of serve fruit of the service tree, service tree, from Old English syrfe, from Vulgar Latin *sorbea, from Latin sorbus service tree

def.dt: :an Old World tree (Sorbus domestica) resembling the related mountain ashes but having larger flowers and larger edible fruit
:a related Old World tree (S. torminalis) with bitter fruits
Robert William 1874–1958 Canad. writer
:a book setting forth forms of worship used in religious services
:the area in which a player stands while serving in various court games (as squash or handball)
:a flat-topped visor cap worn as part of a military uniform compare garrison cap
:the altitude at which under standard air conditions a particular airplane can no longer rise at a rate greater than a small designated rate (as 100 feet per minute)
:a fee charged for a particular service often in addition to a standard or basic fee called also service fee
